DOC.HEAD: Anonymous Letters Examined
DOC.TEXT: Investigators probing mail bombs that killed a federal judge and a civil rights lawyer are examining anonymous letters mailed last summer that threatened the federal judiciary, the FBI said Thursday. The letters, which surfaced in Jackson, Miss., Milwaukee, Minneapolis and an undisclosed location in California, may be an important clue in the FBI-led probe of the two fatal mail-bombs in the South, said FBI spokesman Greg Jones. ``We are examining those letters to try to determine whether or not there is a link between those threats in August and the matters at hand today,'' Jones said. The bombs killed Judge Robert S. Vance of the 11th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals and Robert E. Robinson, a Savannah, Ga., alderman and civil rights lawyer. Other parcel bombs were found at the 11th Circuit court in Atlanta and the Jacksonville, Fla. NAACP office. The FBI says it believes all four similarly packaged bombs were mailed from locations in Georgia. The bombs were similarly constructed of nails and explosives, authorities say. Television stations in Jackson, Miss., and Milwaukee received letters bearing Aug. 21 Atlanta postmarks. That was the day before a tear-gas cannister was thrown into the NAACP headquarters in Atlanta, injuring eight people. Jones refused to discuss the contents of the letters but he said they were similar in content. The ones received by WAPT-TV in Jackson and WITI in Milwaukee were titled ``Declaration of War'' against the 11th Circuit Court of Appeals. according to copies made available by the stations. They threatened poison gas attacks on heavily populated areas ``until widespread terror forces the court to adopt the impartial and equitable treatment of all as its highest priority.'' The Justice Department said Tuesday that the investigation is concentrating on racial motivations for the killings and the bomb incidents. FBI Director William Sessions said investigators are checking Vance's court docket. The director said he wouldn't be surprised if a decision Vance once made motivated the killing. Vance ruled in favor of the Jacksonville NAACP on Sept. 15 in a school desegregation case. Jones said all four letters were examined last summer by the FBI crime laboratory in Washington but yielded no physical clues such as fingerprints. U.S. Marshals in the various jurisdictions where the letters were received were told of the threats, he said.
